Project.Title: Deciding in a fishbowl? The effects of three types of transparency on perceived legitimacy of the judiciary

OrgUnit.Name: Utrecht University School of Governance - USG
Departement Bestuurs- en Organisatiewetenschap
Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance
Faculteit Recht, Economie, Bestuur en Organisatie - REBO

Project.Abstract: Transparency of public institutions has gained 'quasi-religious' significance: it is widely regarded as a hallmark of good governance. Recently the judiciary has been pressured into becoming more transparent about who makes decisions (input transparency), how decisions are made (process transparency), and why something is decided (output transparency). For instance, additional functions of judges are disclosed and verdicts have been made easier to understand for a non-legal public. A key debate is whether this judicial transparency strengthens perceived legitimacy. Adequate legitimacy is crucial to acceptance of judicial decisions and an effective judiciary. Transparency optimists argue that transparency strengthens legitimacy because it leads to more public understanding of judicial decision-making. According to transparency pessimists ?deciding in a fishbowl? undermines legitimacy: prying citizen eyes make the judiciary vulnerable for easy external criticism. Systematic evidence is lacking about under which contextual conditions what type of transparency affects perceived legitimacy. This project answers the following question: When and why, does what type of judicial transparency affect perceived legitimacy? I employ a mixed-methods approach, combining the richness of in-depth interviews with the rigor of experiments. Project outcomes benefit public administration scholarship as follows: 1) Improving transparency theory by developing and testing a taxonomy of three types and three conditions. Input, process, and output transparency will be tested under a varying conditions of outcome favorability, procedural fairness and case complexity. 2) Enriching public administration by using an interdisciplinary approach. Insights from social psychology improve our understanding of citizen responses to judicial transparency. 3) Advancing experimental public administration, which is still in an infant stage, by using a sophisticated 3x2 factorial design in three clusters of two experiments. Project outcomes also benefit practitioners as synthesized results are published in a policy brief, presented at a symposium. This brief helps practitioners to make better informed decisions about judicial transparency.
